bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 8, 1900

div1.p: Lazear reports that the yellow fever epidemic seems to be over, and that the board is hard at work studying Cuban infectious diseases.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 8, 1900
div1.p:
I was glad
to get your letter yesterday.
I enjoyed hearing about
the people at Hatley
and the golf although
I must say I do not
care to take up the
game again. One of
the consolations for being
here is that one does
not have to play golf.
They have a course at the
next post - Guanajoy
but they have never
succeeded in getting one
here. In fact the officers
have no sport except
riding. The soldiers
however play base-ball
nearly all day long.

The drills are early in
the morning so they have
nearly the whole day
for amusements. They are
not allowed to go to
the towns. The epidemic
of yellow fever seems
to be over. Our board
is hard at work in
the laboratory. We are
making a thorough study
of the diseases peculiar
to the island. Nearly half our garrison
is ordered away and it is supposed
they are bound for China. The officers
are glad of the chance for active
service. They like the idea of being
associated with the armies of the
other powers. We are all much
interested in affairs in China and
the delay in getting news here is trying.
They have cut down our mails
to three a week. It makes as
seem farther off than ever.
Gen. Wood has given our board the
use of a two seated vehicle, which
is a great pleasure to us as well
as an assistance in our works.
The weather continues good and
aside from the lack of energy that
goes with the climate all are
doing well.

I hope this will reach you
before you leave Hatley
